subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US COVID-19 cases rose by 18,106 (+1.4%) to 1,342,594 (Prev. +1.3%) and the death toll rose by 1,064 (+1.3%) to 80,820 (Prev. +1.1%). (Newswires)

NIH's Fauci said the US death count is "almost certainly" above the official toll, while he also noted that at least 8 candidate COVID-19 vaccines are currently in development but suggested it is too far to think there will be treatments or vaccines to facilitate the return of school students in the Autumn and that there is no guarantee that a vaccine is going to be effective. (Newswires)

US House Democrats are moving ahead with a new stimulus bill worth more than USD 3tln. This follows earlier reports that US House Leader Hoyer expects the new Democratic coronavirus legislation to be ready this afternoon and expects to meet on Friday for a possible vote on the legislation, while there were also comments from US Senate Majority Leader McConnell that he will insist on a narrow coronavirus response bill if there is to be one and Republican Senator Thune said the House relief bill will not advance in the senate. (CNN/Newswires)

White House Advisor Hassett said the consensus among the White House is to wait to see the effects of reopening the economy before finalising a decision on the final stage of COVID-19 legislation. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron have agreed to open the Franco-German border again, according to reports citing information from the Elysée Palace. Furthermore, reports added they are still working on the details of a return to the normal Schengen system without controls and Federal Interior Minister Seehofer still has to agree to this. (Handelsblatt)

 

ASIA-PAC

US Republican Senators introduced a China sanctions legislation in relation to the mistreatment of Uighur Muslims. (Newswires)

China said it will roll out temporary support for businesses that have suffered a shock or brought to a standstill by COVID fallout, while it will boost aggregate demand, step-up private investment and consumer spending. Furthermore, China will accelerate the replenishment of capital for mid- and small-sized banks, while it will also strengthen stock and bond market support for SMEs too. (Newswires)

China's Finance Ministry have released a second list of tariff waivers for some US goods with exemptions to last 1-year from May 19th, while 79 products were on the exemption list including rare earth ore. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry reiterated that US and China should implement the trade deal, while it stated that China's suspension of beef imports from Australia are not linked to the investigations into the pandemic's origin. (Newswires)

White House advisers expressed opposition to Federal Pension Fund investing in Chinese companies. (Newswires)

Japanese government spokesperson said they are considering subsidies for firms taking social distancing steps, alongside assistance for the auto sector. (Newswires)

Indian PM Modi announced a special economic package totalling INR 20tln, while he added that the tax system is to be rationalised and will strengthen the financial system. (Newswires)

  • Indian Industrial Production (Mar) Y/Y -16.7% vs. Exp. -8.7% (Prev. 4.5%, Rev. 4.6%). (Newswires)
  • Indian Manufacturing Production (Mar) -20.6% (Prev. 3.2%, Rev. 3.1%)

 

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak said UK 'jobs retention scheme' will be extended for four months through the end of October and that funding will be kept at 80% of wages, while the government will ask employers to share cost of furlough scheme with more details by the end of the month. Sunak also stated there will be no changes to the scheme until end of July and that employers will be able to bring back furloughed workers on a part-time basis from August. (Newswires)

UK is reportedly on course to having a budget deficit of GBP 337bln this year compared to the GBP 55bln in the budget, according to reports citing a government document. (Telegraph)

BoE's Broadbent said the MPC is prepared to do what is needed when questioned about negative interest rates, while he added that the Bank keeps all policy tools under review and must consider if more harm than good would be done with negative rates. (Newswires)

ECB's Stournaras said markets do not seem to believe the GCC's decision will be a grave issue on ECB monetary policy and that they work to find a solution to avoid any serious consequences. (Newswires)

ECB's Kazimir said he is not opposed to increasing PEPP but should be based on data and must first examine the impact on the economy from lockdown easing. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 8th May) +7.6mln (exp. +4.1mln, prev. +8.4mln). (Newswires) OPEC+ reportedly wants to keep oil production cuts of 9.7mln BPD beyond June and not to scale back according to OPEC+ sources, while a source said that Russia would not rule out a rollover of the existing cuts beyond June although it will depend on the market situation. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak and US Energy Minister Brouillette discussed measures to stabilise oil markets. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that US energy companies are starting to look very good as oil prices are rising due to cuts from Saudi Arabia. (Twitter)

EIA cut 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 2.9mln BPD to a decline of 8.13mln BPD Y/Y and its 2021 world oil demand forecast was cut by 580k BPD to 6.99mln BPD Y/Y increase, while it sees inventories to begin drawing in July 2020 and with draws continuing through the end  of 2021. (Newswires) 

 

US

US President Trump said that as long as other countries are receiving benefits of negative rates, the US should accept the gift. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (voter, hawk) said banks should not be issuing large dividends at the moment, while he reiterated the recovery will be uneven and that Q2 will be painful. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (voter, dove) said he would be against negative rates citing the impact on intermediaries and money market funds, while he is sceptical that benefits would outweigh the costs. Kaplan also called for Fed actions to be complimented by more fiscal stimulus and argued that it will be necessary. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (voter, dove) said policymakers have been unanimous in opposing negative rates, but added that he does not want to say 'never' on negative rates although there are other things the Fed would need to do first. (Newswires)

Fed Quarles (voter, hawk) said developing both main-street and municipal lending facilities are the Fed's top priority, which will be operational in weeks not months. Quarles also said he expects the 2020 stress test results to be completed sooner than the end of June "given the current environment" and that the unemployment rate will be extremely high in the near-term. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said the fiscal response has been extensive but suspects more needs to get done as the recovery is likely to be slower than first thought. Barkin also stated the theory of new ETF purchase program is that "a little bit of money" could settle things so trading continues on its own, while Barkin also stated the Fed has plenty of balance sheet capacity which can be used to respond if other problems to develop. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bullard (non-voter, dove) said negative rates are not a good option for the US and that the next step for US would be more explicit return to QE, while he added that interest rates are expected to stay low with or without strategies like YCC. (Newswires)

  • US CPI (Apr) M/M -0.8% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. -0.4%). (Newswires)
  • US CPI (Apr) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 1.5%)

 

MARKET RECAP

It has been another indecisive session, and stocks are trading with a negative bias due to US/China headlines, giving up earlier gains. Downside was extended once again in late trade with little new newsflow. Treasuries are bull-flattening amid conflicting signals on risk; the Treasury sold 10-year notes in a record sized offering, and demand is certainly clear even at these low yield levels, with the auction stopping through the screens and seeing decent internals. Oil picked up on further supply side supportive factors, while gold continues to consolidate around USD 1700. In Fedspeak, officials have generally pushed back against the notion of negative rates, and attention will be on Fed Chair Powell’s remarks due on Wednesday morning. CPI data missed to the downside, in another sign that the macro data is grim; while this won’t change the narrative at this moment in time, these data will be eyed more closely in the coming months to see how reopenings are affecting the data. Stimulus headlines have had a muted impact, as Democrats in the House present a USD 3trln Bill, including more direct payments to Americans, USD 1trln support for states and local government, and USD 75bln for testing and tracing; the Republicans have heavily leaned back against the package, suggesting it would not clear the Senate. Uber UBER) reportedly approached GrubHub (GRUB) with a takeover offer, according to sources, which note UBER proposed an all-stock merger and the two continue to discuss a potential tie-up. GRUB is said to seek 2.15 UBER shares for each GRUB share, although UBER said to only offer 2 shares. Boeing Company (BA) CEO expects passenger traffic will not return to 25% of pre-COVID-19 levels by September, but perhaps towards 50% by the end of the year. However, CEO Calhoun does not expect traffic to return to normal for three years. Tesla (TSLA) CEO Musk tweeted that Tesla is restarting production against Alameda County rules with himself working alongside the employees. The Walt Disney Company (DIS) is reportedly accepting hotel reservations on its site from July 1st, according to Travel Weekly. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) has been suggested by Elliott Advisors to explore a sale. Hyatt (H) announced it is to lay off up to 1300 workers and cut pay for senior management, board members, and employees in its restructuring move. SPX -2.1% at, NDQ -2% at 9112, DJIA -1.9% at 23,765.

The TPLEX traded firmer on Tuesday amid the duration bazooka Treasury supply, lacklustre risk appetite, and China risk. Treasuries had been richening ahead of the record size 10-year auction, supported by a 0.8% M/M decline in April CPI, in addition to equity downside as US futures struggled to break key resistance levels after the cash open. The USD 32bln 10-year auction stopped through the 0.712% WI by 1.2bps, covered 2.69x (vs average 2.46x), while dealers took just 20.52% (vs average 26.3%) – a successful all-round auction amid the new record refunding. Note that concession for the auction may have already taken place in prior sessions, in which the 10-year yield had risen from lows of 61bps on Friday to 70bps at the time of today’s auction. The Fed’s activeness in the market may have also limited pushing yields much further, despite the 30-year auction on Wednesday and the continued deluge of corporate deals; not to mention the new 20-year maturity arriving next week. Post the auction, duration continued to catch a bid after reports that GOP Senators had introduced new China sanctions legislation due to its treatment of Uighur Muslims. By settlement, the curve had firmly bull flattened. US T-note futures (M0) settled 10+ ticks higher at 138-30+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 12th: Risk sours as US introduces China sanctions legislation
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: US CPI falls 0.8% in April; largest ever 10-year US auction; Trump endorses negative rates while Fed officials push back; OPEC+ wants to maintain cuts beyond June; China announces new US tariff waivers, US introduces China sanctions legislation
  • COMING UP: Data: US PPI, UK GDP. Events: RBNZ rate decision, DoE inventories. Speakers: Fed Chair Powell; ECB’s Lane & de Guindos. Supply: US, UK, GE, IT

MARKET WRAP

It has been another indecisive session, and stocks are trading with a negative bias due to US/China headlines, giving up earlier gains. Downside was extended once again in late trade with little new newsflow. Treasuries are bull-flattening amid conflicting signals on risk; the Treasury sold 10-year notes in a record sized offering, and demand is certainly clear even at these low yield levels, with the auction stopping through the screens and seeing decent internals. Oil picked up on further supply side supportive factors, while gold continues to consolidate around USD 1700. In Fedspeak, officials have generally pushed back against the notion of negative rates, and attention will be on Fed Chair Powell’s remarks due on Wednesday morning. CPI data missed to the downside, in another sign that the macro data is grim; while this won’t change the narrative at this moment in time, these data will be eyed more closely in the coming months to see how reopenings are affecting the data. Stimulus headlines have had a muted impact, as Democrats in the House present a USD 3trln Bill, including more direct payments to Americans, USD 1trln support for states and local government, and USD 75bln for testing and tracing; the Republicans have heavily leaned back against the package, suggesting it would not clear the Senate.

NORTH AMERICA

US/CHINA: Overnight, Fox reported US President Trump wants pension fund money invested in the Thrift Savings plan to pull investments out of Chinese equities; reports said that there were around USD 4.5bln of these investments in Chinese stocks, however, the more important takeaway is that the US administration is apparently looking at measures to restrict portfolio flows, and that is a risk desks have been keeping an eye out for as US/China rhetoric is ramped ahead of November elections. Meanwhile, GOP Senators and Lyndsey Graham introduced a China sanctions legislation in relation to the mistreatment of Uighur Muslims, the latest move likely to further impact relations between the two nations. Elsewhere, on trade, China released the second raft of tariff waivers for US goods that will be exempted from China’s trade war tariffs, effective next week and will last one year up to May 19th. A total of 79 products have been included – comprising of rare earth ores, semiconductor parts, aircraft radar equipment, medical equipment, chemical, petrochemical products, and some precious metals – albeit the imports values of the products were not disclosed. Importers need to apply within six months to be considered for the waivers – “Tariffs that have already been levied will be refunded,” the statement said. The first round of exclusions was announced back in September last year – these included agri such as soybean and pork alongside petrochemical goods.

CENTRAL BANKS

NEGATIVE FFR: Several Fed speakers came out in aversion to negative rates again on Tuesday, ahead of Fed Chair Powell’s scheduled speech on Wednesday at 0900 ET. Kashkari (voter, dove) said policymakers have been unanimous in opposing negative rates, reiterating that he does not want to say ‘never’, but there are other things the Fed would need to do first. Kaplan (voter) said he would be against negative rates, citing the impact on intermediaries and money market funds; he is sceptical that the benefits would outweigh the costs. Bullard (non-voter) said negative rates are not a good option for the US, noting that the next step for the US would be a more explicit return to QE; Bullard said interest rates are expected to stay low, with or without strategies like YCC. As the list of Fed officials grows larger warning against the policy the Fed Funds futures market has begun to fade some of its recent strength which had taken contracts as near as November above par last week – March ’21 is the closet contract above par currently. However, efforts from Fed officials to walk back NIRP expectations were thwarted, somewhat, today after President Trump tweeted that the US should benefit from the “gift” of negative interest rates – ramping up the political pressure on Powell for Wednesday.

FED SPEAK: Kaplan (voter) called for the Fed’s actions to be complemented by more fiscal stimulus, arguing it will be necessary, echoing Chair Powell - and other Fed officials - in wake of the recent FOMC; Barkin (non-voter) made similar comments again today. Kaplan warned that some businesses will be lost during this crisis, including restaurants and service sector firms. Elsewhere, Fed’s Harker (voter) said banks should not be issuing large dividends at the moment. On the economy, Harker noted the recovery will be uneven, and Q2 will be painful but wants to ensure every sector has access to liquidity. Newswire regular Bullard (non-voter, dove) thinks that the shutdown could last around 120 days without further knock-on effects. Bullard said that the Fed’s balance sheet, at USD 10trln, sounds high, and he expects programmes to wind down as the crisis eases - for reference, the size of the balance sheet is around USD 6.7trln, and many analysts expect it to rise to between 8-10trln in the months ahead.

BOE: BoE's Broadbent, when questioned about negative interest rates, stated the MPC is prepared to do what is needed, and the bank must consider if more harm than good would be done with NIRP. Broadbent added the bank keeps all policy tools under review. Broadbent stated the aim of QE is to help the Bank meet its inflation target and not finance the government.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 10+ TICKS HIGHER AT 138-30+

The TPLEX traded firmer on Tuesday amid the duration bazooka Treasury supply, lacklustre risk appetite, and China risk. Treasuries had been richening ahead of the record size 10-year auction, supported by a 0.8% M/M decline in April CPI, in addition to equity downside as US futures struggled to break key resistance levels after the cash open. The USD 32bln 10-year auction stopped through the 0.712% WI by 1.2bps, covered 2.69x (vs average 2.46x), while dealers took just 20.52% (vs average 26.3%) – a successful all-round auction amid the new record refunding. Note that concession for the auction may have already taken place in prior sessions, in which the 10-year yield had risen from lows of 61bps on Friday to 70bps at the time of today’s auction. The Fed’s activeness in the market may have also limited pushing yields much further, despite the 30-year auction on Wednesday and the continued deluge of corporate deals; not to mention the new 20-year maturity arriving next week. Post the auction, duration continued to catch a bid after reports that GOP Senators had introduced new China sanctions legislation due to its treatment of Uighur Muslims. By settlement, the curve had firmly bull flattened.

CREDIT: The NY Fed’s Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCFF) today went operational in its purchases of corporate ETFs. As it stands, it is now quite clear if it actually purchased any ETFs today, but the announcement caught a lot of media attention, while the large US IG ETF (LQD) and US HY ETF (HYG) were both firmer on the session despite poor risk appetite, perhaps due to Fed purchases, or more likely, participants front-running expected Fed purchases, as has been the case since the facility’s announcement. The SMCFF term sheet notes that it would “avoid purchasing shares of eligible ETFs when they trade at prices that materially exceed the estimated net asset value (NAV) of the underlying portfolio,” therefore, as both LQD and HYG currently trade slightly firmer than NAV, it remains to be seen if the Fed would currently be purchasing such ETFs, as well as what defines a price that “materially exceeds” NAV – it could be that the Fed would initiate its purchases in some of the less liquid ETFs that trade at discounts to the NAV, saving most of its ammo for times of acute stress, such as the March blowout.

THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The Treasury will auction USD 42bln 3-year notes (Mon), USD 32bln 10-year notes (Tue), and USD 22bln 30-year bonds (Wed). This week’s auction will be revealing, given the Treasury’s boosted refunding announcement last week. UBS notes that this week, around USD 86bln cash will fall due, including around USD 58bln of redemptions and USD 29bln of coupons.

PREVIEW - 30-YEAR AUCTION: A more significant concession might be appropriate, relative to the 10-year supply, BMO believes, noting within the 1.35-1.40% range, the 30-year sector has continued to underperform the balance of the curve, which has led to re-steepening particularly in 2s10s and 5s30s; BMO believes more steepening could be in store as a result of the front-end of the curve being anchored to monetary policy expectations, and the second wave of steepening is likely to occur when evidence of upward pressure on inflation is seen; for the time being, the probability of inflation expectations spiking any time soon is limited.

30-YEAR AUCTIONS RECENT HISTORY:

  • High yield: (prev. 1.325%, six-auction avg. 1.964%)
  • Tail: (prev. -0.5bps, six-auction avg. -0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.35x, six-auction avg. 2.40x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 22.6%, six-auction avg. 19.8%)
  • Direct: (prev. 11.0%, six-auction avg. 16.5%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 66.4%, six-auction avg. 63.8%)

CRUDE

WTI FUTURES (M0) SETTLES USD 1.64 HIGHER AT USD 25.78; WTI (N0) SETTLES USD 1.25 HIGHER AT USD 26.33; BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 0.29 HIGHER AT USD 29.98

Crude oil futures were firmer on Tuesday, particularly WTI, after finding support from constructive OPEC+ comments in addition to the latest EIA forecasts. Note that after Monday, where futures failed to sustain their bid after Saudi, Kuwait, and UAE announced they would be making additional cuts, futures managed to hold ground today, catching a spike higher on a sources piece hitting the tape that OPEC+ wants to keep oil production cuts of 9.7mln BPD beyond June, and not to scale back the cuts. Meanwhile, later session gains had been attributed to the EIA’s latest monthly report, which suggested inventories would begin drawing in July 2020 and continuing through the till the end of 2021. Separately, US President Trump tweeted that US energy companies are starting to look very good as oil prices are rising due to cuts from Saudi Arabia. However, Dallas Fed’s Kaplan said the Permian Basin output will shrink by a million BPD, and will see bankruptcies and restructuring – which he said could take until the end of 2021 to work off excess inventories. Participants now look ahead to this week’s US inventory reports, with the private data due later today, ahead of the EIA release on Wednesday; current expectations (bbls): crude +4.1mln, gasoline -2.2mln, distillates +2.9mln.

EIA cut its 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 2.9mln BPD to 8.13mln BPD Y/Y decrease; 2021 world oil demand forecast cut by 580k BPD to 6.99mln BPD Y/Y increase. 2020 US crude output is to fall by 540k BPD (prev. 470k BPD) to 11.69mln BPD; 2021 US crude output is to fall by 790k BPD (prev. 730k BPD) to 10.90mln BPD.

DATA

US CPI: US consumer prices fell 0.8% M/M in April (in line with consensus, prev. -0.4%) and 0.3% Y/Y (slightly short of consensus, prev. 1.5%); the core measure fell by 0.2% M/M (exp. -0.2% M/M, prev. -0.1%) and 1.4% Y/Y (exp. 1.7% Y/Y, rev. 2.1%). It was the second straight negative M/M print. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that the headline was weighed on by gas prices (which shaved 0.6ppts off the headline) though this was partially offset by the biggest rise seen in food prices in 46 years (+2.6% M/M), as meat prices surged amid reduced supply. The consultancy believes that core forecasts always looked too optimistic, given that March only captured the start of the lockdown. Within the details, it was notable that rent prices, which make up over 40% of the core CPI measure, rising by 0.2% M/M, short of the trend rate. Ahead, Pantheon notes that core inflation at 1.4% is down from 2.4% just two months ago, and it expects a further decline in the readings ahead, taking it to beneath 1.0% Y/Y by July, though it does not expect sustained deflation, explaining that the collapse in components like clothing prices, for example, will be limited by the rotation of seasonal inventory and the reopening of retail stores, while airline traffic and hotel occupancy rates are now gradually rising, albeit from incredibly depressed levels.

CHINESE INFLATION (APR.): CPI YY rose 3.3% vs. Exp. 3.7%, down from the prior 4.3%. The easing price pressures were mainly a factor of increased food supply amid a post-virus recovery in production. Food prices rose 14.8% YY, down 3.5 ppts from March. Core CPI edged lower from 1.2% to 1.1%. Meanwhile, PPI fell 3.1% YY, a deeper fall than the forecast 2.6%, with the decline rate accelerating for the third month in a row- impacted by the declines in commodities in the international markets due to the pandemic. The data overnight was largely side-lined as focus shifted onto developments on the US-Sino trade front – with the metrics potentially proving obsolete should tensions between the nations ramp up.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -2.1% at, NDQ -2% at 9112, DJIA -1.9% at 23,765.

SECTORS: Real Estate -4.3%, Industrials -2.8%, Financials -2.7%, Energy -2.4%, Discretionary -2.3%, Technology -2.1%, Materials -1.6%, Health Care -1.5%, Utilities -0.9%, Staples -0.9%, Staples -0.9%, Communications -0.5%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Uber UBER) reportedly approached GrubHub (GRUB) with a takeover offer, according to sources, which note UBER proposed an all-stock merger and the two continue to discuss a potential tie-up. GRUB is said to seek 2.15 UBER shares for each GRUB share, although UBER said to only offer 2 shares. Boeing Company (BA) CEO expects passenger traffic will not return to 25% of pre-COVID-19 levels by September, but perhaps towards 50% by the end of the year. However, CEO Calhoun does not expect traffic to return to normal for three years. Tesla (TSLA) CEO Musk tweeted that Tesla is restarting production against Alameda County rules with himself working alongside the employees. The Walt Disney Company (DIS) is reportedly accepting hotel reservations on its site from July 1st, according to Travel Weekly. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) has been suggested by Elliott Advisors to explore a sale. Hyatt (H) announced it is to lay off up to 1300 workers and cut pay for senior management, board members, and employees in its restructuring move.

EARNINGS: Simon Property Group (SPG) missed on EPS and revenue, although it announced it is planning to open half of its properties within the next week. Both Caesars (CZR) and Eldorado Resorts (ERI) missed on EPS and revenue, while CZR announced it plans to resume operations at some of its properties when it is allowed by those in charge of the reopening, although it notes it cannot accurately predict when consumers will return to normality. It also added that casinos in Louisiana could open as early as this weekend. DataDog (DDOG) beat on EPS and revenue while it also guided analyst expectations for both FY and Q2. Hertz (HTZ) missed on EPS and revenue, while also noting management may not be able to repay or refinance its debt facilities before maturities and it may not have enough cash from operations or liquidity to sustain its operating needs or meet obligations over the next year.

FX WRAP

USD, CNH: The dollar failed to hold onto gains and DXY tumbled back beneath the 100 mark from highs of 100.55 to lows of 99.65. The dollar sell-off was accompanied with lower yields while risk overall was cautious; equities flat/down, cyclicals mixed. The majority of Fed speakers leaned back against negative rates, although US President Trump is an advocate. China’s offshore yuan gave back gains against the dollar, amid more punchy rhetoric between the two nations, that has traders on edge once again ahead of Presidential elections in November. Attention will be on the PBOC’s yuan fixing overnight after news that some US Senators had introduced legislation to slap sanctions on the nation due to their treatment of minorities. On the data front, Chinese consumer prices missed expectations, which analysts have said bolsters the case for the central bank to add support.

JPY: USDJPY reversed some of the gains seen on Monday due to the weakness in the greenback, although the continued punchy US/China rhetoric was adding JPY support and some desks continue to eye JPY as a US/China hedge. Elsewhere on yesterday’s upside, JPMorgan are not really sure this is the start of anything too impressive in the JPY market other than a reversal of the relative exuberance towards the JPY we have seen over the past week and remains on the sideline for now.

CYCLICALS (AUD, NZD, GBP): Cyclicals were hit on continued US/China rhetoric, although AUD was particularly lower overnight after China banned four Australian beef exporters signalling a further deterioration in the relationship between the two after Australia called for an investigation into the origin of the coronavirus, where China warned that this could see a Chinese consumer boycott. However, overnight losses were pared amid a falling dollar, and AUD seemed magnetic to 0.65 through US trade. NZD saw similar price action although fared better than its Antipodean counterpart given the rising tensions between China and Australia. GBP saw further downside today and resides around the 1.2275 mark at pixel time. Chancellor Sunak today announced they will be extending the furlough scheme from June to October and will continue to pay 80% of wages. The scheme is costing GBP 8bln a month, Sunak said, who added employers will be asked to share the cost of the scheme. On the monetary side, BoE’s Broadbent noted al policy tools are under review and when questions about NIRP he stated “the MPC is prepared to do what is needed”, seemingly not ruling out negative rates, but neither advocating for it.

COMMODITY FX (CAD, RUB, MXN): Overall petrocurrencies are mixed, both CAD and MXN failed to benefit from the weaker dollar and firmer oil prices, though the RUB did benefit. Oil settled firmer after a choppy session after its additional cut bid yesterday while it was further supported on sources that OPEC+ want to maintain level of current production cuts, rather than taper them down, while the latest EIA forecasts also supported the crude space. Despite oil gains/USD weakness, CAD was likely hampered by reports that retailers in Quebec reopening dates have been pushed back from this week until May 25th, while MXN may not be liking news that the military has been asked to return to the streets for the next five years, perhaps hampering consumer sentiment, with some holding opposition to the move stating soldiers and marines have frequently been accused of human rights violations, the Guardian reported. RUB held onto gains, albeit off best levels.

EMFX: EMFX was mixed, TRY, ZAR, and RUB were the outperformers as TRY continues its reversal from Friday and USDTRY now trades back beneath the 7.00 figure despite the ban on short selling from foreign banks being removed. Elsewhere, BRL underperformed once again despite BCB minutes signaling limits to the scope of further easing. However, in a further blow to President Bolsonaro reports note the Former Minister of Justice Lawyer noted the recording of the ministerial meeting confirms the statement from Bolsonaro that he wanted a new chief of police for personal reasons to “receive information and intelligence reports”. After accusations of the statement, the Attorney General stated if this was true, Bolsonaro has broken numerous laws.

EUR: The single currency benefitted from the dollar weakness today, while little has changed on the GCC court ruling, a judge noted that the message to the ECB was very mild, while ECB’s Stournaras noted markets do not seem to believe its decision will be a grave issue on monetary policy although a solution is needed to avoid serious consequences.

THIS WEEK'S CRUDE INVENTORY EXPECTATIONS: Crude +4.1mln, gasoline -2.2mln, distillates +2.9mln
TREASURY WRAP: T-Note futures (M0) settle 10+ ticks higher at 138-30+
analysis_details:
The TPLEX traded firmer on Tuesday amid the duration bazooka Treasury supply, lacklustre risk appetite and China risk. Treasuries had been richening ahead of the record size 10-year auction, supported by a 0.8% M/M decline in April CPI, in addition to equity downside as US futures struggled to break key resistance levels after the cash open. The USD 32bln 10-year auction stopped through the 0.712% WI by 1.2bps, covered 2.69x (vs average 2.46x), while dealers took just 20.52% (vs average 26.3%) – a successful all-round auction amid the new record refunding. Note that concession for the auction may have already taken place in prior sessions, in which the 10-year yield had risen from lows of 61bps on Friday to 70bps at the time of today’s auction. The Fed’s activeness in the market may have also limited pushing yields much further, despite the 30-year auction on Wednesday and the continued deluge of corporate deals; not to mention the new 20-year maturity arriving next week. Post the auction, duration continued to catch a bid after reports that GOP Senators had introduced new China sanctions legislation due to its treatment of Uighur Muslims. By settlement, the curve had firmly bull flattened...

CREDIT: The NY Fed’s Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCFF) today went operational in its purchases of corporate ETFs. As it stands, it is not quite clear if it actually purchased any ETFs today, but the announcement caught a lot of media attention, while the large US IG ETF (LQD) and US HY ETF (HYG) were both firmer on the session despite poor risk appetite, perhaps due to Fed purchases, or more likely, participants front-running expected Fed purchases, as has been the case since the facility’s announcement. The SMCFF term sheet notes that it would “avoid purchasing shares of eligible ETFs when they trade at prices that materially exceed the estimated net asset value (NAV) of the underlying portfolio,” therefore, as both LQD and HYG currently trade slightly firmer than NAV, it remains to be seen if the Fed would currently be purchasing such ETFs, as well as what defines a price that “materially exceeds” NAV – it could be that the Fed would initiate its purchases in some of the less liquid ETFs that trade at discounts to the NAV, saving most of its ammo for times of acute stress, such as the March blowout.

30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: A more significant concession might be appropriate, relative to the 10-year supply, BMO believes, noting within the 1.35-1.40% range, the 30-year sector has continued to underperform the balance of the curve, which has led to re-steepening particularly in 2s10s and 5s30s; BMO believes more steepening could be in store as a result of the front-end of the curve being anchored to monetary policy expectations, and the second wave of steepening is likely to occur when evidence of upward pressure on inflation is seen; for the time being, the probability of inflation expectations spiking any time soon is limited.

subject: US Senate Majority Leader McConnell says he will insist on a narrow coronavirus response bill if there is to be one
analysis_details:
• Republicans are pushing back against the notion of further stimulus, ahead of House Speaker Pelosi's 15:00 ET speech, when she will talk abot her USD 3trln stimulus bill. Senator Thune recently said it will not advance in the Senate, while Advisor Hassett stated the consensus among the White House is to wait and see the effects of reopening the economy before finalising a decision on the final stage of COVID-19 legislation.
  • In recent days, Administration officials have indicated that negotiations were ongoing; however, some senior GOP members have leaned-back against the notion that any blockbuster-sized stimulus will be in the next Bill, stating that Democrats were trying to use the crisis to push through longer-term spending objectives; additionally, there was a desire to see how current measures were working before adding further stimulus.
  • That said, the Fed has suggested that both fiscal and monetary policy makers would need to do more in the months ahead to support a sustainable recovery - the Fed has indicated that it is willing, although signs from Capitol Hill have been more lukewarm.

subject: CRUDE WRAP: WTI futures (M0) settles USD 1.64 higher at USD 25.78; WTI (N0) settles USD 1.25 higher at USD 26.33; Brent (N0) settles USD 0.29 higher at USD 29.98
analysis_details:
Crude oil futures were firmer on Tuesday, particularly WTI, after finding support from constructive OPEC+ comments in addition to the latest EIA forecasts. Note that after Monday, where futures failed to sustain their bid after Saudi, Kuwait, and UAE announced they would be making additional cuts, futures managed to hold ground today, catching a spike higher on a sources piece hitting the tape that OPEC+ wants to keep oil production cuts of 9.7mln BPD beyond June, and not to scale back the cuts. Meanwhile, later session gains had been attributed to the EIA’s latest monthly report, which suggested inventories would begin drawing in July 2020 and continuing through the till the end of 2021. Separately, US President Trump tweeted that US energy companies are starting to look very good as oil prices are rising due to cuts from Saudi Arabia. However, Dallas Fed’s Kaplan said the Permian Basin output will shrink by a million BPD, and will see bankruptcies and restructuring – which he said could take until the end of 2021 to work off excess inventories. 

INVENTORY FORECASTS: Participants now look ahead to this week’s US inventory reports, with the private data due later today, ahead of the EIA release on Wednesday; current expectations (bbls): crude +4.1mln, gasoline -2.2mln, distillates +2.9mln.

EIA STEO: The EIA cut its 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 2.9mln BPD to 8.13mln BPD Y/Y decrease; 2021 world oil demand forecast cut by 580k BPD to 6.99mln BPD Y/Y increase. 2020 US crude output is to fall by 540k BPD (prev. 470k BPD) to 11.69mln BPD; 2021 US crude output is to fall by 790k BPD (prev. 730k BPD) to 10.90mln BPD.

GOP Senators and Lyndsey Graham have introduced a China sanctions legislation in relation to the mistreatment of Uighur Muslims
content: • Click here for link
analysis_details:
Coronavirus

US President Trump and other members of the administration have stated they have evidence that the coronavirus originated from a lab in Wuhan, and many have noted they will be held accountable.

Portfolio flows

Last night, US President Trump wants pension fund money invested in the Thrift Savings plan to pull investments out of Chinese equities; reports said that there were around USD 4.5bln of these investments in Chinese stocks, however, the more important takeaway is that the US administration is apparently looking at measures to restrict portfolio flows, and that is a risk desks have been keeping an eye out for as US/China rhetoric is ramped ahead of November elections.

Trade

Over the weekend and yesterday, Chinese Vice Premier Liu He, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer spoke over the phone and agreed to keep communications, strengthen cooperation and vowed efforts to implement the phase 1 deal. The sides reportedly agreed to work together to create a beneficial environment for carrying out the trade deal, while they agreed good progress was made to make deal a success and that both sides fully expect obligations to be met. Subsequently, SCMP reported that a Chinese Gov’t Adviser, on the US-China phone call, suggested that the fact that “the dialogue has now gone straight to ministerial level may indicate the problem is quite severe”. This was later followed by US President Trump noting he is having a hard time with China in regard to the deal, although no final decision has yet been made. NEC Director Kudlow held the same view, noting the relationship is complex, adding they have not been transparent and will be held accountable once the final results are in, although he did not say how. China has now also been called on by the US Chamber of Commerce to dramatically accelerate its US good purchases under the Phase One trade deal as China’s economy returns to normality.

subject: PREVIEW: Treasury to auction 3-year on Mon, 10-year on Tue, 30-year on Wed; bias is towards a steeper curve, analysts say
content:
TACTICAL BIAS: Fed guidance on rates (staying at these low levels for the foreseeable), buying concentrated in the belly, and the possibility of yield curve control (YCC) is outweighing the flood of bill supply in the short-end of the curve, TD Securities argues, keeping rates anchored at low levels. Meanwhile, the long-end of the curve is under pressure as a result of rising Treasury supply. This should give the curve a steeper bias.

THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The Treasury will auction USD 42bln 3-year notes (Mon), USD 32bln 10-year notes (Tue), and USD 22bln 30-year bonds (Wed). This week's auction will be revealing, given the Treasury's boosted refunding announcement last week. UBS notes that this week, around USD 86bln cash will fall due, including around USD 58bln of redemptions and USD 29bln of coupons.

3-YEAR AUCTIONS RECENT HISTORY

  • High yield: (prev. 0.348%, six-auction avg. 1.189%)
  • Tail: 1.2bps (prev. , six-auction avg. 0.7bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.28x, six-auction avg. 2.44x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 40.5%, six-auction avg. 35.9%)
  • Direct: (prev. 4.1%, six-auction avg. 13.9%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 55.4%, six-auction avg. 50.2%)

10-YEAR AUCTION: There is still demand for 10-year even at slightly higher yields than present, analysts say, citing price action after Wednesday’s Treasury refunding announcement when 10-year yields closed 3-4bps higher, but rallied on Thursday back to within the 0.60-65% range (and respected the 0.78% top-end of its broader range). BMO argues, and that the liquidity advantages of Treasury auctions will continue to bring in buyers, and notes that sponsorship seen in recent auctions has come despite a dramatic repricing in yields, and we have seen several stop-throughs at record low yields, even with record auction sizes. BMO thinks this is an encouraging sign that the supply can be absorbed with little concession, and it does not expect the broader 0.54-0.78% 10-year Treasury yield range will be challenged as a result of this week’s supply. It does, however, think there is a risk the high-yield could stop-out above 0.70%.

10-YEAR AUCTIONS RECENT HISTORY

  • High yield: (prev. 0.782%, six-auction avg. 1.462%)
  • Tail: (prev. 0.7bps, six-auction avg. -0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.43x, six-auction avg. 2.46x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 27.6%, six-auction avg. 26.3%)
  • Direct: (prev. 13.2%, six-auction avg. 14.2%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 59.2%, six-auction avg. 59.6%)

30-YEAR AUCTION: A more significant concession might be appropriate, relative to the 10-year supply, BMO believes, noting within the 1.35-1.40% range, the 30-year sector has continued to underperform the balance of the curve, which has led to re-steepening particularly in 2s10s and 5s30s; BMO believes more steepening could be in store as a result of the front-end of the curve being anchored to monetary policy expectations, and the second wave of steepening is likely to occur when evidence of upward pressure on inflation is seen; for the time being, the probability of inflation expectations spiking any time soon is limited.

30-YEAR AUCTIONS RECENT HISTORY

  • High yield: (prev. 1.325%, six-auction avg. 1.964%)
  • Tail: (prev. -0.5bps, six-auction avg. -0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.35x, six-auction avg. 2.40x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 22.6%, six-auction avg. 19.8%)
  • Direct: (prev. 11.0%, six-auction avg. 16.5%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 66.4%, six-auction avg. 63.8%)

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed Funds futures for the turn of the year rose above par last week, signalling a probability above zero that the Fed could lower rates into negative territory next year. The moves above par were modest, and pared back at the end of the week (Nov 2020 FF was above par early Friday, but only the Feb 2021 contract closed out the week at/above par). Goldman Sachs is surprised by market's implying negative yields (even if modest) given that Fed speakers have generally been averse to such moves. GS says that, while it is hard to rule out, the pricing in seems a bit aggressive given current expectations for the economy, and even if the Fed were to explore negative rates, it would likely be reluctant to go deep, given political issues with penalising cash. Other think the pricing of negative rates might be more technical in nature.

JAPANESE BUYERS: Talk of Japanese buyers coming back into the market makes sense, and the yen depreciating while Treasuries were rallying is consistent with that thesis. FX-hedged Treasuries for Japanese investors are looking somewhat attractive. Japanese had been buyers of Treasuries on an unhedged basis recently, and now they are attractive again on a hedged basis, and BMO would expect to see inflows continue from one of the largest-holders of Treasuries. However, it remains to be seen at what levels investors want to buy 30-year debt at.

content:
USD

The Greenback was already losing momentum before US CPI missed expectations on all counts bar the m/m headline index, and perhaps more pertinently both core measures that strip out energy prices. However, further gains were unwound vs most major counterparts and EM currencies amidst a swathe of Fed rhetoric adding weight to the argument against negative rates, but highlighting the rationale behind aggressive policy stimulus and actions taken to combat the effects of COVID-19. The DXY appears to have found support and underlying bids in to 99.500, but the index remains well off best levels between 100.440-99.653 extremes in choppy conditions ahead of Fed chair Powell’s speech on Wednesday and with President Trump repeating his penchant for NIRP.

NOK/SEK/EUR/CHF

Prime beneficiaries of the Buck’s change of fortunes, with the Norwegian Crown quickly regrouping after a post-Q1 GDP wobble to resume its bull run with assistance from firm crude prices, while the Swedish Krona kept pace and both managed to outdo the Euro even though the single currency staged an impressive recovery from sub-1.0800 lows vs the Dollar before fading around 1.0885. Indeed, Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek have retested recent lows and key technical levels within 11.1855-11.0220 and 10.7100-10.5785 respective ranges, with the latter now eyeing inflation data tomorrow and expectations from Prospera on Thursday. Elsewhere, the Franc is now firmly over 0.9700 and still keeping the SNB on its toes in cross terms near 1.0500 before Swiss import and producer prices that may well turn more deflationary in the same vein as CPI.

NZD/AUD/JPY

Also taking advantage of ‘turnaround Tuesday’ for the Greenback, with the Kiwi and Aussie back on big figure levels at 0.6100 and 0.6500 vs lows under 0.6050 and sub-0.6450 overnight, but heading into big potential independent drivers in the form of the RBNZ policy meeting (preview available via our Research Suite or Headline Feed) and April jobs report. Meanwhile, the Yen has bounced from circa 107.70 to over 107.25 against the backdrop of bull re-flattening along the US Treasury curve and awaiting Japanese trade and current account data.

CAD/GBP

Relative G10 underperformers, or more rangebound against the Usd, but the Loonie did get a fillip to cross 1.4000 on the back of reports that 4 OPEC+ members want to keep the reduced output cap beyond the May-June period currently agreed to, in contrast to Sterling that stayed under pressure following dovish/downbeat comments from BoE’s Broadbent. Cable never really looked comfortable on the 1.2300 handle and Eur/Gbp rebounded to 0.8830 from just shy of 0.8760 at one stage, with UK GDP due before the midweek EU (and Liffe) ‘open’.

EM

Broad appreciation vs the Buck, but eye-catching for obvious reasons is the Lira continuing its comeback to reclaim 7.0000+ status despite the ban on foreign banks being lifted, while the Real took some note of BCB minutes highlighting less room for further easing and the Mexican Peso was relieved that IP was not as bad as anticipated or feared.

subject: ANALYSIS: CPI prints negative for a second straight month, but analysts do not see sustained deflation
analysis_details:
• US consumer prices fell 0.8% M/M in April (in line with consensus, prev. -0.4%) and 0.3% Y/Y (slightly short of consensus, prev. 1.5%); the core measure fell by 0.2% M/M (exp. -0.2% M/M, prev. -0.1%) and 1.4% Y/Y (exp. 1.7% Y/Y, rev. 2.1%). It was be the second straight negative M/M print.
  • Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that the headline was weighed on by gas prices (which shaved 0.6ppts off the headline) though this was partially offset by the biggest rise seen in food prices in 46 years (+2.6% M/M), as meat prices surged amid reduced supply. The consultancy believes that core forecasts always looked too optimistic, given that March only captured the start of the lockdown. Within the details, it was notable that rent prices, which make up over 40% of the core CPI measure, rising by 0.2% M/M, short of the trend rate. 
  • Ahead, Pantheon notes that core inflation at 1.4% is down from 2.4% just two months ago, and it expects a further decline in the readings ahead, taking it to beneath 1.0% Y/Y by July, though it does not expect sustained deflation, explaining that the collapse in components like clothing prices, for example, will be limited by the rotation of seasonal inventory and the reopening of retail stores, while airline traffic and hotel occupancy rates are now gradually rising, albeit from incredibly depressed levels.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: Equities see a choppy open amid further push back on negative rates from Fed officials, although Trump is in favour
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: Risk sentiment was knocked overnight on news that China was to ban some meat imports from Australia, and suggestions that US President Trump wants pension fund money invested in the Thrift Savings plan to pull investments out of Chinese equities; reports said that there were around USD 4.5bln of these investments in Chinese stocks, however, the more important takeaway is that the US administration is apparently looking at measures to restrict portfolio flows, and that is a risk desks have been keeping an eye out for as US/China rhetoric is ramped ahead of November elections. Market sentiment has stabilised as the Europeans arrived. However, SPX opened with marginal gains although gains which have since reversed to negative territory amid a further pushback on negative rates from Fed’s Bullard (Dove) and Kaplan (voter), joining Evans and Bostic, with eyes on Powell tomorrow. Yields are moving lower, and the curve is flattening ahead of 10-year supply; the DXY is slightly down around 40bps, while gold continues to consolidate around USD 1,700. Oil is higher with desks attributing yesterday’s announcements from Saudi/Kuwait/UAE on additional supply curbs, although it failed to sustain gains at the time.  SECTORS: The majority of sectors initially opened in positive territory although many are now in negative after a move lower in equities overall. Defensives (Staples, Health Care, Utilities) lead the way, although Materials among those led by post earnings gains in International Flavours and Fragrance (IFF) and Amcor (AMCR). Elsewhere, Real Estate is the laggard despite the announcement from SPG that it is planning to reopen half of its stores within a week. Health care is flat and Technology in the red after a solid day of gains yesterday.  

STOCK SPECIFCS: Boeing Company (BA) CEO expects passenger traffic will not return to 25% of pre-COVID-19 levels by September, but perhaps towards 50% by the end of the year. However, CEO Calhoun does not expect traffic to return to normal for three years. Tesla (TSLA) CEO Musk tweeted that Tesla is restarting production against Alameda County rules with himself working alongside the employees. The Walt Disney Company (DIS) is reportedly accepting hotel reservations on its site from July 1st, according to Travel Weekly. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) have been suggested by Elliott Advisors to explore a sale. Hyatt (H) announced it is to lay off up to 1300 workers and cut pay for senior management, board members, and employees in its restructuring move. 

EARNINGS: Simon Property Group (SPG) missed on EPS and revenue, although it announced it is planning to open half of its properties within the next week. Both Caesars (CZR) and Eldorado Resorts (ERI) missed on EPS and revenue, while CZR announced it plans to resume operations at some of its properties when it is allowed by those in charge of the reopening, although it notes it cannot accurately predict when consumers will return to normality. It also added that casinos in Louisiana could open as early as this weekend. DataDog (DDOG) beat on EPS and revenue while it also provided guidance above analyst expectations for both FY and Q2. Hertz (HTZ) missed on EPS and revenue, while also noting management may not be able to repay or refinance its debt facilities prior to maturities and it may not have enough cash from operations or liquidity to sustain its operating needs or meet obligations over the next year.  

TOP STORIES: NY Fed said it would begin buying US corporate debt ETFs. China announced the batch of new US tariff waivers, although Sino-Aussie tensions are ramping up; meanwhile China CPI eased. Energy giant Saudi Aramco profit was down 25% as oil prices collapsed. BOE’s Broadbent is keeping negative rates in the toolbox.

LEVELS: ES remains within the key 2,925-35 range (fibs, valuation); upside break brings 2,965 (Apr hi) into focus, then 3,000 (200dma, psych); downside eyes 2,890-2,900 (valuation, psych) then 2,873 (8dma).

CORPORATE BONDS: The NY Fed said that its Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF) will on 12th May begin purchases of ETFs whose investment objective is to provide broad exposure to the market for US corporate bonds. It will consider several factors in determining which ETFs to purchase, including the composition of IG and non-IG rated debt, the management style, the amount of debt held in depository institutions, the average tenor of underlying debt, the total assets under management, the average daily trading volume, and leverage, if any. Note that in its term sheet it said it would not purchase ETFs with market prices that "materially exceed" their NAV. This should provide a further tailwind for corporate bonds, analysts believe. Full analysis here.    

US/CHINA: Despite some sourced articles in recent days calling into question whether China should abide by the Phase One trade deal, the official line from China remains that the deal should implemented, according to headlines today. However, the question may be more about whether it remains feasible. Goldman Sachs notes that the USD 200bln purchase agreement looks increasingly challenging due to COVID-19 and low energy prices, and that November’s Presidential Election may make it harder for US policymakers to strike a conciliatory tone on China given public opinion in the US has turned more negative towards the nation. But for now, these trade tensions appear to be a secondary focus, GS says citing its proprietary US/China trade tension indicators, which suggests that China-related assets have not been driven much by risk related to trade tensions. And similarly, the bank notes that the correlation of Mainland China risk proxies with its Risk Appetite Indicator has fallen significantly. But GS still thinks that the renewed US-China trade tensions could represent an additional source of negative shocks. “Our China equity strategists' trade tensions barometer suggests markets are still factoring in a relatively benign outcome for the bilateral trade relationship; in equities, Kospi and HSCEI implied volatility is near historical lows compared to the S&P 500 and could be an attractive hedge to this risk.”    

AAPL: UBS Evidence Lab team thinks that there could be pent-up demand for AAPL products with consumers’ purchase intent improving, and consumers having more discretionary spend available (fewer vacations, dining out, etc.). Its Asia supply chain work suggests improvement in build plans for the June quarter, and besides a replacement cycle driven upgrade cycle, it believes 5G could also play a role , and says it is comfortable with its C21 iPhone unit estimate of roughly +25% Y/Y). UBS smartphone survey of 7k consumers across five countries showed strong improvement in purchase intent, and improving intent for Apple in all regions. It also notes that services is becoming more material part of Apple's gross profit, and given the recurring nature of the business, it suggests that it should help AAPL’s stock multiple - accounted for 39% of gross profit in March quarter, and though March is a seasonally weak quarter for products, for the FY it expects services to account for 35% of gross profit, and is forecasting services gross profit mix to be higher than 41% on an annual basis over the next five years. UBS explains its PT is based on around 20x its calendar 2021 estimated EPS of USD 16.22. AAPL is trading at around 22x forward EPS and above the 5-year to 10-year average of around 14x, UBS says, and it is trading at a 6% premium to S&P versus its 1-year average of 7%. “We believe a slight premium to history is justified given possibly stronger 2021 and long-term opportunities from 5G/foldable phones, wearables, and new services.”

Fed's Kashkari (voter) notes US government is able to borrow cheaply, has the ability to raise funds to support Americans
content:
• Kashkari, a dove, says you don't want to issue so much debt that investors lose confidence; when crisis is over, you will need to put house in order
  • says we are not going to fix the economy until we can control the virus
analysis_details:
• Kashkari is referring to longer-dated US yields at historically low levels; yesterday, Mnuchin suggested that the US government take advantage of this to finance recovery programmes; Kashkari appears to be endorsing that view.
  • Fed officials have recently been urging lawmakers to bring further stimulus, with Chair Powell recently noting that both monetary and fiscal policymakers would need to do more.
  • This line of commentary also follows last week's Treasury refunding announcement, where longer-dated issuance was boosted.

subject: Fed’s Bullard (non-voter) says negative rates are not a good option for the US; says next step for US would be more explicit return to QE; interest rates are expected to stay low, with or without strategies like YCC
content:
• Fed’s efforts to support the market have worked quite well; facilities have had a good effect just through their announcement
  • Bullard thinks that shutdown could last around 120 days without further knock-on effects
  • Fed's balance sheet, at USD 10trln, sounds high; Bullard expects programmes to wind down as the crisis eases (for reference, the size of the balance sheet is around USD 6.7trln, and many analysts expect it to rise to between 8-10trln in the months ahead)
analysis_details:
• Fed Fund futures for April 2021 are at par - last week, we saw negative implied in the pricing of the November 2020 contract, though this has pared.
  • Most Fed officials have suggested that negative rates will not be appropriate for the US, although they have not aggressively ruled out the policy in the future.
  • It is also interesting that Bullard suggested that the next step could be more QE - analysts have speculated that the Fed is likely to eventually go for a Japanese/Australian-style YCC policy to control shorter-dated parts of the curve, in combination with a pledge to keep rates low for a prolonged time. Of course, YCC would require an element of QE, so his remarks are not entirely inconsistent with that theory.

May 12th, 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • China released the second raft of tariff waivers for US goods that will be exempted from China’s trade war tariffs, effective next week and will last one year up to May 19th. A total of 79 products have been included – comprising of rare earth ores, semiconductor parts, aircraft radar equipment, medical equipment, chemical, petrochemical products, and some precious metals – albeit the imports values of the products were not disclosed.

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) UBS Evidence Lab team thinks that there could be pent-up demand for AAPL products with consumers’ purchase intent improving, and consumers having more discretionary spend available (fewer vacations, dining out, etc.). Its Asia supply chain work suggests an improvement in build plans for the June quarter, and besides a replacement cycle driven upgrade cycle, it believes 5G could also play a role, and says it is comfortable with its C21 iPhone unit estimate of roughly +25% Y/Y). UBS smartphone survey of 7k consumers across five countries showed strong improvement in purchase intent, and improving intent for Apple in all regions. It also notes that services are becoming more material part of Apple’s gross profit, and given the recurring nature of the business, it suggests that it should help AAPL’s stock multiple - accounted for 39% of gross profit in March quarter, and though March is a seasonally weak quarter for products, for the FY it expects services to account for 35% of gross profit and is forecasting services gross profit mix to be higher than 41% on an annual basis over the next five years. UBS explains its PT is based on around 20x its calendar 2021 estimated EPS of USD 16.22. AAPL is trading at around 22x forward EPS and above the 5-year to 10-year average of around 14x, UBS says, and it is trading at a 6% premium to S&P versus its 1-year average of 7%. “We believe a slight premium to history is justified given possibly stronger 2021 and long-term opportunities from 5G/foldable phones, wearables, and new services.”
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) CEO expects passenger traffic will not return to 25% of pre-COVID-19 levels by September, but perhaps towards 50% by the end of the year. However, CEO Calhoun does not expect traffic to return to normal for three years.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) is reportedly accepting hotel reservations on its site from July 1st, according to Travel Weekly. However, no formal announcement has been made.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) – UBS expects to see SSS of 7% for the full quarter, consisting of a 3% core SSS in February, 18% in March and 6% in April as stay-at-home orders went into effect. The desk writes, in almost any scenario, the retail giant should emerge in a better position than it was before the pandemic, noting how a change in consumer behaviour will benefit WMT in areas of low prices, omnichannel shopping, trip consolidation, and only groceries.

subject: Abbott Laboratories (ABT) has received FDA emergency use authorisation for COVID-19 molecular test on new Alinity M system
White House advisers express opposition to Federal Pension Fund investing in Chinese companies
analysis_details: Risk sentiment was knocked overnight amid suggestions (via Fox News) that US President Trump wants pension fund money invested in the Thrift Savings plan to pull investments out of Chinese equities; reports said that there were around USD 4.5bln of these investments in Chinese stocks, however, the more important takeaway is that the US administration is apparently looking at measures to restrict portfolio flows, and that is a big risk that desks have been keeping an eye out for as US/China rhetoric is ramped ahead of November elections; any restrictions on investment flows would represent a major escalation in US/China tensions, analysts have said.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt remains divergent and Dollar deflated
content: Broadly benign and softer than forecast US inflation data has hardly impacted in the grand scheme and given weaker CPI and other price metrics to come, but core bonds are still diverging in phases or legs and the Buck is unwinding more gains forged yesterday to a fresh mtd high for the DXY, with the index threatening to slip further below the 100.000 mark. Of note in particular, the Antipodes and Scandis are gleaning impetus from the Greenback’s retreat amidst renewed risk appetite, with EM currencies also taking advantage and the Turkish Lira back above 7.0000. However, sentiment and price action is whippy and prone to change abruptly on breaking news and headlines. Back to debt markets, Gilts carved out another new Liffe high at 137.49 before fading again, while Bunds slipped to a slightly deeper Eurex base at 172.91 and USTs are holding in range with a flatter bias.

subject: US PRE-MARKET THEMES: China headlines keeps traders defensive ahead of US CPI
analysis_details:
PRE-MARKET ACTION: Risk sentiment was knocked overnight on news that China was to ban some meat imports from Australia, and suggestions that US President Trump wants pension fund money invested in the Thrift Savings plan to pull investments out of Chinese equities; reports said that there were around USD 4.5bln of these investments in Chinese stocks, however, the more important takeaway is that the US administration is apparently looking at measures to restrict portfolio flows, and that is a risk desks have been keeping an eye out for as US/China rhetoric is ramped ahead of November elections. Market sentiment has stabilised as the Europeans arrived, and as the US day gets underway, the tone is more constructive, with ES futures back within the 2,925-2,935 zone; yields are mixed but the bias of the curve is leaning steeper ahead of 10-year supply; the DXY is slightly off neutral (USDCNH around unchanged), while gold continues to consolidate around USD 1,700. Oil is higher with desks attributing yesterday’s announcements from Saudi/Kuwait/UAE on additional supply curbs, although it failed to sustain gains at the time.

AHEAD: US CPI for April is expected to print a negative M/M reading for the second straight month, primer here. US 10-year supply at the new upsized levels, preview here. We’ll also be keeping an eye for any Fedspeak on YCC or negative rates (Powell is due to speak Wednesday); and also keeping an eye out for any commentary on the US/China front about specific measures that are to be enacted (restricting portfolio flows might be taken as very risk-off by market participants). On the virus front, NIH director Fauci will testify to Senate at 1000 ET/1500 BST, and reports suggest he will warn against opening the economy too quickly.  

TOP STORIES: NY Fed said it would begin buying US corporate debt ETFs. China announced the batch of new US tariff waivers, although Sino-Aussie tensions are ramping up; meanwhile China CPI eased. Energy giant Saudi Aramco profit was down 25% as oil prices collapsed. BOE’s Broadbent is keeping negative rates in the toolbox.

LEVELS: ES remains within the key 2,925-35 range (fibs, valuation); upside break brings 2,965 (Apr hi) into focus, then 3,000 (200dma, psych); downside eyes 2,890-2,900 (valuation, psych) then 2,873 (8dma).

CORPORATE BONDS: The NY Fed said that its Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF) will on 12th May begin purchases of ETFs whose investment objective is to provide broad exposure to the market for US corporate bonds. It will consider several factors in determining which ETFs to purchase, including the composition of IG and non-IG rated debt, the management style, the amount of debt held in depository institutions, the average tenor of underlying debt, the total assets under management, the average daily trading volume, and leverage, if any. Note that in its term sheet it said it would not purchase ETFs with market prices that "materially exceed" their NAV. This should provide a further tailwind for corporate bonds, analysts believe. Full analysis here.

US/CHINA: Despite some sourced articles in recent days calling into question whether China should abide by the Phase One trade deal, the official line from China remains that the deal should implemented, according to headlines today. However, the question may be more about whether it remains feasible. Goldman Sachs notes that the USD 200bln purchase agreement looks increasingly challenging due to COVID-19 and low energy prices, and that November’s Presidential Election may make it harder for US policymakers to strike a conciliatory tone on China given public opinion in the US has turned more negative towards the nation. But for now, these trade tensions appear to be a secondary focus, GS says citing its proprietary US/China trade tension indicators, which suggests that China-related assets have not been driven much by risk related to trade tensions. And similarly, the bank notes that the correlation of Mainland China risk proxies with its Risk Appetite Indicator has fallen significantly. But GS still thinks that the renewed US-China trade tensions could represent an additional source of negative shocks. “Our China equity strategists' trade tensions barometer suggests markets are still factoring in a relatively benign outcome for the bilateral trade relationship; in equities, Kospi and HSCEI implied volatility is near historical lows compared to the S&P 500 and could be an attractive hedge to this risk.”

AAPL: UBS Evidence Lab team thinks that there could be pent-up demand for AAPL products with consumers’ purchase intent improving, and consumers having more discretionary spend available (fewer vacations, dining out, etc.). Its Asia supply chain work suggests improvement in build plans for the June quarter, and besides a replacement cycle driven upgrade cycle, it believes 5G could also play a role , and says it is comfortable with its C21 iPhone unit estimate of roughly +25% Y/Y). UBS smartphone survey of 7k consumers across five countries showed strong improvement in purchase intent, and improving intent for Apple in all regions. It also notes that services is becoming more material part of Apple's gross profit, and given the recurring nature of the business, it suggests that it should help AAPL’s stock multiple - accounted for 39% of gross profit in March quarter, and though March is a seasonally weak quarter for products, for the FY it expects services to account for 35% of gross profit, and is forecasting services gross profit mix to be higher than 41% on an annual basis over the next five years. UBS explains its PT is based on around 20x its calendar 2021 estimated EPS of USD 16.22. AAPL is trading at around 22x forward EPS and above the 5-year to 10-year average of around 14x, UBS says, and it is trading at a 6% premium to S&P versus its 1-year average of 7%. “We believe a slight premium to history is justified given possibly stronger 2021 and long-term opportunities from 5G/foldable phones, wearables, and new services.”

subject: ANALYSIS: US Small Business survey shows expectations jumping, but hint at weaker inflation ahead
analysis_details:
• Small business sentiment fell in April to 90.9 from 96.4, better than the 83.0 the Street was looking for.
  • A key stand out was the economic expectations component, which rose by 5 points to 29; hiring intentions rose to 1 from -8. That said, the rest of the details echoed the downbeat tone of recent macro releases; expectations for firms' own sales slid to -42 from -30, and earnings expectations fell to -20 from -14, and inventory build plans fell to -4 from -1.
  • The divergence between improving expectations and expectations for their own sales declining is perhaps capturing the idea that the overall economy cannot get much worse, Pantheon Macroeconomics said, so the future has to be better than the past.
  • There is also some insight into price pressures; The NFIB’s selling price measure dropped to -18, a 10-year low, from +6. Pantheon notes, adding that when adjusted for the impact of falling gasoline prices, this is consistent with core CPI inflation dipping below 1 to 1.5% over the next few months. (The March print was 2.1%, and that is expected to fall to 1.7% in today's data; preview for the April CPI here)

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses opened marginally lower but have since been bolstered as US participants enter the fray; US futures firmer as such
  • US President Trump stated he is not happy with China and that he is not interested in reopening the US-China trade deal
  • China's Finance Ministry have released a second list of tariff waivers for some US goods; exemptions will last 1-year from May 19th
  • NY Fed said the Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility will begin purchases of ETFs today which may purchase US-listed ETFs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI, EIA STEO, Fed's Bullard, Harker, Mester, supply from the US. NIH’s Fauci speaking.

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

NIH’s Fauci is to warn the Senate there are risks of reopening too soon which can lead to needless suffering and death. (NYT)

US Treasury released details on USD 150bln state aid from coronavirus relief fund in which it is to make direct payments to state governments and territories, while the funds may only be used to cover expenses related to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

US CDC reported total coronavirus cases as of previous day increased to 1,324,488 (Prev. 1,300,696) and total death toll was at 79,756 (Prev. 78,711), while AFP noted the total number of US deaths have surpassed 80,000 citing the Johns Hopkins tracker. (Newswires) An emergency hospital set up in New York's Central Park started to be dismantled on Monday with the city past the worst of the pandemic, while a temporary hospital was set up in Washington DC in the event there is a jump in infections. (Newswires/AFP)

Philippines extended the lockdown in biggest cities of Manila and Cebu until May 31st. (Newswires)

China's Health Commission says the resurfacing of cluster cases in China suggests prevention and control measures cannot be relaxed. (Newswires)

Japan's Finance Minister does not think that tax cuts are an option at present, not amongst the package of steps to combat the economic fallout from COVID-19; fiscal situation is severe. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded cautiously following the indecisive performance of their Wall St peers as US-China trade concerns resurfaced with President Trump later noting he was not interested in renegotiating the phase on deal after earlier reports suggested that China could opt for a renegotiation. ASX 200 (-1.1%) suffered broad losses amid weak business confidence and as escalating tensions with China added to the glum after Australia’s largest trading partner imposed an import ban on 4 Australian abattoirs which some viewed to be retaliation for PM Morrison’s calls for an independent inquiry to the coronavirus outbreak. Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) was subdued by unfavourable currency flows and with focus on earnings releases including Toyota which was pressured after it failed to provide net guidance due to the virus and saw a slump in its FY operating profits. Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were also lacklustre due to the increased trade concerns surrounding China but with downside in the mainland cushioned by recent stronger than expected lending data. Mixed trade across the European equity sphere thus far [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%] as the downbeat sentiment from the APAC session somewhat waned as European trade went underway. Italy’s FTSE MIB (+0.7%) outperforms the region as banks continue to feel tailwinds from yesterday’s reports that Italy’s Gov’t is said to be mulling state guarantees for up to EUR 15bln of bonds issued by banks. Sectors are mixed, but defensives broadly outperform cyclicals; with the breakdown painting a similar picture. Telecom names stand as the marked outperformer as earnings from giant Vodafone (+8.1%) bolster the sector. Vodafone’s stellar FY prelim results see a YY rise across group revenue, adj. EBITDA, and operating profit, whilst Q4 organic services revenue topped forecasts and FY guidance for Adj. EBIT and Capex were raised on account of its UK assets merger with Liberty Global. Peers Orange (+1.2%) and Telecom Italia (+2.2%) rise in tandem, albeit gains are less pronounced in BT (+0.2%) shares amid its direct competitor's solid results. The sector also sees tailwinds from ProseibenSat (+11.5%) whose shares were propelled to the top of the Stoxx 600 after KKR acquired ~5.2% stake in the Co, with 3.21% in shares and 2.0% through financial instruments. Turning to other movers; Thyssenkrupp (-9.0%) holds onto post-earning losses on the back of deteriorating Q2 net, deeper negative EPS, and debt almost doubling YY.
